title: What causes ball lightning, and has anyone ever been injured? - Quora

response.answer_text: As of this writing ball lightning is not well understood or even accepted as a real phenomenon by many scientists. Ball lightning - Wikipedia Yes there have been numerous accounts of people being not only injured but also killed. DEVON AND CORNWALL NOTES & QUERIES. : Free Download, Borrow, and Streaming : Internet Archive One early account reports the Great Thunderstorm at a church in Widecombe-in-the-Moor, Devon, in England, on 21 October 1638. Four people died and approximately 60 were injured when, during a severe storm, an 8-foot (2.4 m) ball of fire was described as striking and entering the church, nearly destroying it. Large stones from the church walls were hurled into the ground and through large wooden beams. The ball of fire allegedly smashed the pews and many windows, and filled the church with a foul sulphurous odour and dark, thick smoke. The ball of fire reportedly divided into two segments, one exiting through a window by smashing it open, the other disappearing somewhere inside the church. Because of the fire and sulphur smell, contemporaries explained the ball of fire as "the devil" or as the "flames of hell". Later, some blamed the entire incident on two people who had been playing cards in the pew during the sermon, thereby incurring God's wrath. Sciences skepticism is understandable as it deals with processes that can be repeatable observed, preferable duplicated in the lab. Ball lighting as been frustratingly difficult in this. Here is a picture showing what is believed to be the formation of ball lighting captured in China and published in NewScientist. Natural ball lightning probed for the first time  The cause of ball lightning appears to be the result of a silica plasma forming from a lightning ground strike. The exact conditions for this to happen appear to be rare and are still not understood.

People have been injured, but I don’t think anyone knows what it is or why it forms. It is far too rate a phenomenon to study. I knew a radio ham (in the 50s) who had the stuff come down his aerial, fizzle across the floor, squeezed under the door, along the floor, out through the wall and disappear into the ground at the base of a tree. It did leave a scorched trail, but no real damage.
